newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: SOCCER-FIFA GIVES CHECKS TO GUATEMALA SOCCER VICTIMS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-FIFA GIVES CHECKS TO GUATEMALA SOCCER VICTIMS.

text.p: The families of 78 Guatemalans crushed to death in an overcrowded soccer stadium last year received a check for $6,500 each on Monday from FIFA, the international soccer authority.

"We don't want tragedies. But whenever they happen in World Cup football (soccer) we feel we should indemnify the victims and their families," said Jack Warner, a FIFA vice president who travelled from New York to distribute the checks.

Overcrowding triggered a human avalanche in the cheap seating section of Guatemala City's Mateo Flores stadium on October 16 just minutes before a World Cup qualifying match between Costa Rica and Guatemala.
It was the worst tragedy in the history of soccer's World Cup competition.
Warner said the extent of the tragedy affected him deeply.

"I spoke to one family today who lost five members. A few thousand U.S. dollars could never pay for that. The mother was crying. She was still burdened. After it I couldn't continue, I had to excuse myself," Warner said.

The checks may seem small by the standards of developed nations, but many of the families who lost people in the tragedy were very poor and $6,500 could represent more than double the yearly income of one person.
Warner said the money for the families came out of a "fair play" fund that pools fines against members for penalties and rule infractions.
He said 25 families didn't show up on Monday for checks, but local sports authorities have six months to find them and give them their checks.
Despite Monday's check-giving, the families will continue to seek undetermined damages from the government and sports authorities blamed in the tragedy.

"This is humanitarian aid from FIFA and it is completely separate from the compensation we've asked for from the courts," said Rene Cordoba, the attorney representing most of the families in a civil suit against the state and soccer event organisers.
A presidential commission investigated the tragedy and found extreme overcrowding, no emergency plan and no crowd control devices led to the worst tragedy in World Cup history.
FIFA ordered the stadium closed after the tragedy but in April granted permission for reopening after the Guatemalan Soccer Federation made changes to guarantee security for fans.
